data.Title: Achlysiella nematodes (Achlysiella spp.)

Symptoms.General: Often hard to spot and may look like nutrient or water stress.

data.Life Cycle: Adult females swollen, sausage-shaped. Full life cycle not well understood.
data.Why They Matter: Rare but potentially a biosecurity concern. Monitoring and identification are important to detect any outbreaks early.
Management Options: Keep an eye on sugarcane health in Nth QLD
Send suspicious samples for identification
Follow biosecurity advice to prevent spread
Further Information: Nobbs JM (2003). Preparation of a CD-ROM library of plant parasitic nematodes: Plant parasitic nematodes recorded from sugarcane in Australia. South Australian Research and Development Institute (SARDI), Adelaide, Australia.
Siddiqi MR (2006). Tylenchida: parasites of plants and insects, 2nd ed. Commonwealth Agricultural Bureau, Slough.

data.Title: Foliar, leaf or bud nematodes (Aphelenchoides spp.)
data.Host Range: Strawberry, ferns, lilies, chrysanthemums and other ornamentals.

Symptoms.Leaves/Buds: Necrotic leaf lesions, leaf distortion, malformed buds/growing points.

data.Life Cycle: 10–14 days; survive several months in dry leaves and reproduce in water films on plant surfaces.
data.Why They Matter: Damage leaves and buds, reducing plant vigour and yield.
Management Options: Use nematode-free planting material.
Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Maintain good air circulation and avoid excess moisture on foliage.
Further Information: Jenkins WR, Taylor DP (1967). Plant Nematology. Reinhold Publishing Corporation, New York, USA.

data.Title: Ring Nematodes (Family Criconematidae)
data.Host Range: Woody plants, turfgrass, and native vegetation; specific crop impacts are not well known.

Symptoms.Roots: Subtle damage, may include stunting or reduced function.
Symptoms.Aboveground: Slight decline in vigour, often not obvious.

data.Why They Matter: Often under-sampled due to slow movement and difficult extraction. True economic impact is uncertain but may affect woody plants.
Management Options: Use improved detection methods (e.g., sugar flotation, centrifugation) to identify infestations.
Prevent spread by careful management of soil and plant material.
Further Information: Jenkins WR, Taylor DP (1967). Plant Nematology. Reinhold Publishing Corporation, New York, USA.

f. Criconematidae.Reference: Bull et al 2018; Bhuiyan et al 2020

data.Title: Stem and Bulb Nematodes (Ditylenchus spp.)
data.Host Range: Rice, oat, faba bean, field pea, lentil, canola, onion, garlic, tomato and other.

Symptoms.General: Stunted growth, swollen stem bases, yellow or brown streaks on leaves.

data.Life Cycle: 10–20 days; survives in a dry state within crop residues.
data.Why They Matter: Can reduce crop establishment and yield through damage to stems and bulbs. Potential to spread via infected seed, bulbs, or contaminated soil. Limited knowledge on distribution, host range, and economic impact in Northern Australia highlights the need for monitoring and further research.
Management Options: Use certified nematode-free seed and planting material
Avoid movement of infected soil or plant material
Remove and destroy infected crop residues
Monitor susceptible crops, especially in newly detected regions
Further Information: Bridge J, Starr JL (2007). Plant Nematodes of Agricultural Importance. Manson Publishing Ltd., London.

data.Title: Cyst nematodes (Globodera spp. & Heterodera spp.)
data.Host Range: Potato, sugarcane, cereals (wheat, barley, oat, triticale), legumes (including clovers), beets, brassicas, and others.
data.Life Cycle: 5–-8 weeks. Cysts protect eggs for years
data.Why They Matter: Cause significant yield losses up to 70%. Long-lasting cysts make control difficult.
Management Options: Prevent introduction and spread.
Use resistant varieties and rotate with non-host crops.
Avoid moving soil, plants, or equipment from infested areas.
Monitor crops regularly for symptoms.
Further Information: Blacket MJ, Agarwal A, Wainer J, Triska MD, Renton M, Edwards J (2019). Molecular assessment of the introduction and spread of potato cyst nematode, Globodera rostochiensis, in Victoria. Phytopathology 109, 659-669.

Vanstone VA, Hollaway GJ, Stirling GR (2008). Managing nematode pests in the southern and western regions of the Australian cereal industry: continuing progress in a challenging environment. Australasian Plant Pathology 37, 220-234.

data.Title: Pin Nematodes (Paratylenchus spp. & Gracilacus spp.)
data.Host Range: Mint, tall fescue, celery, carnations, figs, and others.

Symptoms.Roots: Usually only affected at high population densities, causing stunted growth.
Symptoms.Aboveground: Subtle decline in vigour, often overlooked.

data.Why They Matter: Populations can rise rapidly (>500 per 100 cm³ soil). Rapid population growth potential makes monitoring and management important.
Management Options: Monitor populations regularly, especially in susceptible crops.
Rotate crops and maintain healthy soils to reduce risk.
Avoid moving infested soil or plants.
Further Information: Claerbout J, Vandevelde I, Venneman S, Kigozi A, de Sutter N, Neukermans J, Bleyaert P, Bert W, Höfte M, Viaene N (2020). A thorough study of a Paratylenchus sp. in glasshouse-grown lettuce: Characterisation, population dynamics, host plants, and damage threshold as keys to its integrated management. Annals of Applied Biology. 178(1), 62–79.

Wood FH (1973). Biology and host range of Paratylenchus projectus Jenkins, 1956 (Nematoda: Criconematidae) from a subalpine tussock grassland. New Zealand Journal of Agricultural Research 16, 381–384.

Paratylenchus sp..Plant Associated: Rhodes grass , tomato, okra, pumpkin, etc.

data.Title: Spiral Nematodes (Helicotylenchus spp., Rotylenchus spp. & Scutellonema spp.)
data.Scientific Name: Helicotylenchus spp., Rotylenchus spp. & Scutellonema spp.
data.Host Range: Banana, horticultural crops, root/tuber crops such as yam.

Symptoms.Roots: Stunted, necrotic, dry rot in yam tubers.

data.Life Cycle: 30–35 days at 24–32°C for some Helicotylenchus species.
data.Why They Matter: H. multicinctus is a major pest in banana, causing significant economic losses. Scutellonema spp. cause dry rot in yam tubers, reducing quality and storage life. Wide host range and prevalence increase potential crop damage.
Management Options: Use resistant or tolerant crop varieties where available.
Rotate with non-host crops to reduce populations.
Maintain good soil health and drainage.
Avoid moving infested soil or plants.
Monitor susceptible crops regularly for early detection.
Further Information: Jenkins WR, Taylor DP (1967). Plant Nematology. Reinhold Publishing Corporation, New York, USA.

Bridge J, Coyne D, Kwoseh CK (2005). Nematode parasites of tropical root and tuber crops. In: Luc M, Sikora R, Bridge J (eds) Plant Parasitic Nematodes in Subtropical and Tropical Agriculture, 2nd edn. CAB International, Wallingford, UK, pp 221-258.

data.Title: Sheath Nematodes (Hemicycliophora spp.)
data.Host Range: Globally: wide range of crops, fruit/nut trees, and ornamentals (e.g., black pepper, banana, cucurbits, citrus, rice, tobacco, yardlong bean, bamboo, cardamom). In Australia: no crop damage reported.

Symptoms.Roots: No observable plant symptoms in Australia.
Symptoms.Aboveground: No observable plant symptoms in Australia.

data.Life Cycle: Varies by species; survives in moist soils.
data.Why They Matter: Several species cause significant crop damage internationally (H. arenaria, H. conida, H. parvana, H. poranga, H. similis, H. typica). Broad host range and potential pathogenicity warrants monitoring.
Management Options: Monitor high-risk areas and susceptible crops.
Maintain soil health and avoid waterlogging.
Further Information: Nguyen HT, Trinh QP, Couvreur M, Nguyen TD, Bert W (2021). Description of Hemicycliophora cardamomi sp. n. (Nematoda: Hemicycliophoridae) associated with Amomum longiligulare T.L. Wu and a web-based key for the identification of Hemicycliophora spp. Journal of Helminthology 95, e2.
Van Gundy SD, Rackham RL (1961). Studies on the biology and pathogenicity of Hemicycliophora arenaria. Phytopathology 51, 393-397.

data.Title: Lance Nematodes (Hoplolaimus spp.)
data.Host Range: Cotton, rice, citrus, sugarcane, mango, tamarind, cowpea, baobab tree, banana, corn, soybean and others.
data.Life Cycle: Thrives in sandy soils; reproduction under suitable conditions. Detailed info is limited.
data.Why They Matter: Reduce rice yields by up to 18% in upland systems. Pot trials: 100–10,000 nematodes per plant reduced tillers by 22–36% and grain yield by 11–18%. Less common than other nematodes but potentially important in sandy coastal soils.
Management Options: Monitor sandy soils, especially in coastal cropping regions.
Rotate with non-host crops or use resistant varieties where available.
Maintain soil health and avoid moving infested soil or plants.
Further Information: Ramana KV, Prasad JS, Seshagiri Rao Y (1978). Influence of atmospheric conditions and soil temperature on the prevalence of the lance nematode (Hoplolaimus indicus Sher, 1963) in rice fields. Proceedings of the Indian Academy of Sciences, Section B 87, 39-43.

Overstreet C, McGawley EC, Khalilian A, Kirkpatrick TL, Monfort WS, Henderson W, Mueller JD (2014). Site-specific nematode management - development and success in cotton production in the United States. Journal of Nematology 46, 309-320.

data.Title: Southern Sting Nematode (Ibipora lolii)
data.Host Range: Turfgrasses (bowling greens, golf tees, putting greens); potential risk to cereals, sugarcane and maize.

Symptoms.Aboveground: Turf decline, often mistaken for other stresses.

data.Why They Matter: Most destructive nematode pest of turfgrass in Australia. Spreads easily in sandy soils. Impacts sports fields and recreational areas.
Management Options: Monitor turfgrass in high-risk areas.
Use clean planting material and treat soil where needed.
Further Information: Siviour TR, McLeod RW (1979). Redescription of Ibipora lolii (Siviour 1978) comb. n. (Nematoda: Belonolaimidae) with observations on its host range and pathogenicity. Nematologica 25, 487-493.

data.Title: Root-knot Nematodes (Meloidogyne spp.)
data.Distribution: Five species confirmed in the region: M. arenaria, M. incognita, M. javanica, M. thamesi, and M. enterolobii.
data.Host Range: 5,000 plant species, including melons, tomatoes, capsicum, cucumber, sweet potato, eggplant, ornamental and pasture plants.
data.Crops at Risk: Tomato, capsicum, watermelon, peanut, mungbean, cucumber, sweetpotato, eggplant, cotton, etc.

Symptoms.Aboveground: Stunted growth, wilting, uneven crop performance, especially under heat or drought stress.

data.Life Cycle: 4-6 weeks at 24-28°C; faster in tropical conditions; female lay up to 1,000 eggs.
data.Why They Matter: Cause 5–20% yield loss or more. M. enterolobii can overcome resistance genes in many crops.
Management Options: Major plant-parasitic nematodes in Northern Australia and worldwide.
Can reduce yields by more than half and cost billions globally.
Thrive in light soils and warm climates, multiplying year-round in northern regions.
M. enterolobii can bypass resistance genes in many crops.
data.Further Information: Hay F, Stirling GR (2014). Management of root-knot nematode in vegetable crops. Horticulture Innovation Australia.

Meloidogyne enterolobli.Plant Associated: Milkweed*, okra*, ginger*,wild poinsettia*, Golden penda*

Meloidogyne javanica.Reference: Goss 1958; Goss & Hawson 1969; Cobon et al. 2022

data.Title: Needle Nematodes (Paralongidorus spp.)
data.Host Range: Mainly perennial crops; P. australis notably impacts rice in Nth QLD.
data.Why They Matter: Cause serious disease in rice and potentially other perennial crops. Serve as vectors for certain plant viruses, increasing biosecurity risks. Probably more widespread than reported due to limited surveys in the north.
Management Options: Monitor susceptible crops, especially rice.
Use clean planting material and avoid moving infested soil.
Rotation or fallow may help in annual crops, but options are limited in perennials.
Maintain crop health (adequate nutrition, moisture, and good drainage) to reduce impact.
Further Information: Stirling GR, Vawdrey LL (1985). Distribution of a needle nematode, Paralongidorus australis, in rice fields and areas of natural vegetation in North Queensland. Australasian Plant Pathology, 14, 71-72.

Stirling GR (2023). Ectoparasitic plant-parasitic nematodes known to cause crop damage in Australia. In: Stirling GR (ed) Australian plant-parasitic nematodes: applications and management. APPsNet. https://www.appsnet.org/nematodescontents.

data.Title: Stubby Nematodes (Paratrichodorus spp.)
data.Host Range: Tomatoes, corn, onions, sugarcane, grapefruit, and others.

Symptoms.Roots: Shortened and thickened; reduced fine feeder rootlets.

data.Life Cycle: 16–22 days at 22–30°C; grow best in sandy loam soils.
data.Why They Matter: Can transmit plant viruses. Damage roots and reduce nutrient/water uptake.
Management Options: Monitor susceptible crops, especially in high-risk areas.
Manage soil health and structure to limit nematode population build-up.
Use clean planting material and avoid moving infested soil.
Further Information: Jenkins WR, Taylor DP (1967). Plant Nematology. Reinhold Publishing Corporation, New York, USA.

Paratrichodorus sp..Plant Associated: Sorghum, rhodes grass, tomato, onion, pumpkin, melon, etc.
Mango, Avocado, Lime, Unidentified grassland flora

data.Title: Root-lesion nematodes (Pratylenchus spp.)
data.Host Range: Wide range of crops including cereals, sugarcane, turf, grape, stone fruit, pome fruit, pineapple.

Symptoms.Roots: Lesions, rots, and destruction of feeder roots.
Symptoms.Aboveground: Stunted plants with yellowing leaves and fewer tillers, often seen in patches across the paddock.

data.Why They Matter: Major pests worldwide but often underestimated because root symptoms are subtle. Reduce yields by 5–15% in many crops; P. thornei and P. neglectus can cut wheat yields by up to 64% and 32%, respectively. Damaged roots allow other pathogens to enter, worsening plant health.
Management Options: Test soil and roots regularly, as they can be present without obvious symptoms.
Rotate with poor-host crops to lower nematode numbers.
Use resistant or tolerant cultivars or rootstocks where available.
Reduce stress by maintaining good nutrition, organic amendments, and adequate moisture.
Further Information: Thompson JP, Owen KJ, Stirling GR, Bell MJ (2008). Root lesion nematodes (Pratylenchus thornei and P. neglectus): a review of recent progress in managing a significant pest of grain crops in northern Australia. Australasian Plant Pathology 37, 2325-242.

Vanstone VA, Hollaway GJ, Stirling GR (2008). Managing nematode pests in the southern and western regions of the Australian cereal industry: continuing progress in a challenging environment. Australasian Plant Pathology 37, 220-234.

Pratylenchus sp..Plant Associated: Sweet potato, beans, tomato, pumpkin, chilli, etc.

data.Title: Burrowing Nematodes (Radopholus spp.)
data.Host Range: Wide range of crops including bananas, sugarcane, ginger, turmeric, cardamom, peppers, soybeans, sorghum, maize, eggplant, coffee, tomatoes, and potatoes. Some weed species such as annual ryegrass and wild radish can host these nematodes.

Symptoms.Roots: Dark red to black spots that join together.
Symptoms.Aboveground: Weak, yellow, stunted, and produce smaller bunches. In wet, windy weather, weakened roots may cause plants to fall over.

data.Why They Matter: R. similis is the most damaging species, especially to bananas. Severe yield losses reported: 40–70% in oranges, 50–80% in grapefruits, up to 95% over 10 years in bananas.
Management Options: Clean planting material and enforce quarantine measures
Monitor susceptible crops regularly to reduce losses
Implement crop rotation and maintain strict field sanitation
Retain crop residues and apply organic amendments to improve soil health
Further Information: Pattison AB, Cobon JA, Araya-Vargas M, Chabrier C (2024). Towards sustainable management of nematodes in banana. In Drenth A, Kema G (eds.) Achieving sustainable cultivation of bananas Volume 3: Diseases and pests. Burleigh Dodds Science Publishing, p. 419-450.

Stirling GR, Pattison AB (2008). Beyond chemical dependency for managing plant-parasitic nematodes: examples from the banana, pineapple and vegetable industries of tropical and subtropical Australia. Australasian Plant Pathology 37, 254-267.

Radopholus sp..Plant Associated: Tomato, onion, mango, pawpaw, banana, avocado, lime

data.Title: Reniform Nematodes (Rotylenchulus spp.)
data.Host Range: >300 plant species including cotton, cowpea, soybean, tobacco, pineapple, sweetpotato, okra, tomato, beans, various vegetables and weeds.

Symptoms.Roots: Destruction of feeder roots, reduced root volume.
Symptoms.Aboveground: Stunted growth, yellowing, wilting, delayed flowering, fewer and smaller fruits, and overall yield decline.

data.Life Cycle: ≤3 weeks Females embeds their heads in roots; each lays 40–100 eggs.
data.Why They Matter: Rotylenchulus reniformis is the dominant species in northern Australia and a major pest of cotton, vegetables and pineapple. Can cut cotton yields by 10-25% (over 50% in bad seasons). Worsens root diseases and often goes unnoticed due to subtle symptoms.
Management Options: Rotate with non-host crops and manage weeds
Use resistant or tolerant varieties where available
Optimise soil health and drainage to discourage build-up
Avoid spreading infested soil on equipment, tools, or footwear
Further Information: Lawrence KS (2022). Reniform nematode (Rotylenchulus reniformis) and its interactions with cotton (Gossypium hirsutum). In Integrated Nematode Management: State-of-the-art and visions for the future (Eds. RA Sikora et al.) CAB International, Wallingford, Chapter 14, 94-99.

Smith LJ, Scheikowski L, Kafle D (2024). The distribution of reniform nematode (Rotylenchulus reniformis) in cotton fields in central QLD and population dynamics in response to cropping regime. Pathogens 13, 888.

Stirling GR (2023). PSN 031. Reniform nematode (Rotylenchulus reniformis), a damaging pest of many crops in tropical and subtropical regions of Australia. In: Stirling GR (ed) Plant and soil nematodes: friend and foe. APPsNet. https://www.appsnet.org/nematodes

data.Title: Stunt Nematodes (Tylenchorhynchus spp.)
data.Host Range: Rice, corn, wheat, sugarcane, sorghum, citrus, soybean, sweet potato, lettuce, grape, and others.

Symptoms.Roots: Stunted and reduced root mass; corn roots may weigh 40–60% less when infested.
Symptoms.Aboveground: Stunted shoots, yellowing, wilting, and defoliation.

data.Life Cycle: Populations can increase from 10 to 5,000 individuals in ~8 months under favourable conditions.
data.Why They Matter: Cause major root damage, reducing plant growth and yields. Potential to affect many crops in Northern Australia due to wide host range.
Management Options: Monitor soil and root health regularly.
Rotate crops and use resistant varieties where available.
Maintain soil health and avoid practices that encourage nematode build-up.
Further Information: Handoo ZA (2000). A key and diagnostic compendium to the species of the genus Tylenchorhynchus Cobb, 1913 (Nematoda: Belonolaimidae). Journal of Nematology 32(1), 20-34.
Jenkins WR, Taylor DP (1967). Plant Nematology. Reinhold Publishing Corporation, New York, USA.

data.Title: Citrus Nematode (Tylenchulus semipenetrans)
data.Host Range: Primarily citrus, including orange, grapevines, persimmon, lilac, and olive.

Symptoms.Roots: Stunting and general deterioration of roots.
Symptoms.Aboveground: Poor growth and delayed production, known as the citrus replant problem.

data.Life Cycle: 6–8 weeks at 24–26°C: female lays several hundred eggs.
data.Why They Matter: Causes crop losses ranging from 10 to 50%. Serious economic impact due to reduced tree growth and delayed production, especially in replant situations.
Management Options: Use nematode-free planting material
Avoid replanting citrus in heavily infested soils or apply soil treatments before planting
Manage soil salinity and maintain organic matter to reduce nematode reproduction
Regular monitoring of nematode populations in orchards
Further Information: Duncan LW (2005). Nematode parasites of citrus. In: Luc M, Sikora RA, Bridge J (eds) Plant parasitic nematodes in subtropical and tropical agriculture, 2nd ed. CAB International, Wallingford, UK, pp. 437-466.

Stirling GR (2023). PSN 032. Citrus nematode (Tylenchulus semipenetrans), the cause of slow decline of citrus. In: Stirling GR (ed) Plant and soil nematodes: friend and foe. APPsNet. https://www.appsnet.org/nematodes

Tylenchulus sp..Plant Associated: Mango, Avocado, Lime, Unidentified grassland flora

data.Title: Dagger Nematodes (Xiphinema spp.)
data.Host Range: Perennial horticultural crops (fruit trees, grapevines, strawberries, figs, tomatoes), rice, sugarcane, peanuts, soybeans.
data.Life Cycle: 1 year; prefers mild soils (~20°C) with moderate moisture (25–80%).
data.Why They Matter: Damage to root tips limits water and nutrient uptake, lowering yields. Some species transmit plant viruses, increasing biosecurity risks.
Management Options: Use clean planting material and avoid moving infested soil
Rotate crops and use resistant rootstocks when available
Keep crops healthy with good nutrition, moisture, and drainage.
Further Information: Jenkins WR, Taylor DP (1967). Plant Nematology. Reinhold Publishing Corporation, New York, USA.
